instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: 82-3209 no charger light
threads.message: Hello, i have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I/O board was burned, now there is no sighns of life. No orange/green light on charger. 16.5v comes to Logic board. 9ahrtz is changed, but still same. what voltages should i measure?

threads.title: 82-3209 no charger light
threads.message: Used new IO board and new cable? Must have green light first. PPBUS voltage?

threads.title: 82-3209 no charger light
threads.message:
Hello, i have found nominal lost on resistor: <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> changed it.. Now light comes on. Mac works from charger and from battery. But if attach charger when battery is plugged <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and q 7085 burns.

have changed both <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> also <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, but its same.Q burns and light dont come on.

threads.title: 82-3209 no charger light
threads.message:
Are you sure they are soldered on correctly, especially their thermal pads? Any chance you damaged them?
Maybe someone else has any idea because I don't understand how these will "burn" (even when under full load they shouldn't be), these do not have a simple path to ground and also the charger would immediately cut out if it were to happen.

Resistance to ground (in Ohms) on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_INRUSH</SIGNAL>? Using an original adapter or chinese copy?

If you're sure everything is soldered on correctly you might want to try and replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85 and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> all at the same time.

threads.title: 82-3209 no charger light
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85 all at the same time. Check Resistance between pins 17/18, 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
